6 Equipment States and Tracking Requirements
6.1 Equipment States
6.1.1 To measure equipment system performance (e.g., RAM metrics), this Document defines six, mutually exclusive,
basic equipment states into which all equipment conditions and periods of time must shall fall. Any equipment system shall be in one and only one equipmentSEMI E10 state at any point in time. One of these equipment states—
T
unscheduled downtime (UDT)—represents the initial moment of an equipment system failure (i.e., a failure event)
O
until its recovery from that failure event. Because an equipment system is in one and only one equipmentSEMI E10
state at a time, an equipment system is subject to at most one failure at any point in time, regardless of the number of L
underlying problems contributing to or arising from that failure. L
A
6.1.1.1 For certain equipment systems called intended process sets (IPSs) and multi-path cluster tools (MPCTs),
B
independent tracking of equipmentSEMI E10 states is required for each equipment module in these equipment systems.
These equipment modules may be in different equipmentSEMI E10 states at the same time, and they may experience
L
failures independently from each other.
A
6.1.2 The equipment states are determined by function, not by organization. Any given maintenance procedure, for N
example, is classified the same way no matter who performs it (e.g., an operator, a production technician, a
O
maintenance technician, a process engineer).
 Figure 1 is a stack chart of the six basic equipment states. These basic equipment states can be divided into as T
many equipment substates (hereinafter substates) as are required to achieve the equipment tracking resolution that a A
manufacturing operation desires. This Document makes no attempt to list all possible substates, but does define M
mutually exclusive substates for the scheduled downtime state (SDT) and the unscheduled downtime state (UDT).;
R
tThese substates are required to support certain metrics and other examples for guidance. 


  The figure represents an Equipment Time -- State Stack Chart, which decomposes Total Time for a piece of equipment into mutually exclusive and hierarchically related time states.
Total Time refers to the complete calendar time horizon under consideration for the equipment, and it fully contains Operations Time and Nonscheduled Time as disjoint components.
Operations Time is the portion of Total Time during which the equipment is scheduled or expected to be available for operational use, whereas Nonscheduled Time represents periods when the equipment is not planned to be in operation at all and does not overlap with Operations Time.
Within Operations Time, the equipment alternates between Equipment Uptime and Equipment Downtime, and these two states together exactly partition Operations Time.
Equipment Downtime refers to periods when the equipment is unavailable due to maintenance or failure, while Equipment Uptime refers to periods when the equipment is technically available for operation.
Equipment Downtime is decomposed into Scheduled Downtime AND Unscheduled Downtime, where Scheduled Downtime corresponds to planned interruptions such as preventive maintenance AND Unscheduled Downtime corresponds to unplanned interruptions such as failures or breakdowns.
Equipment Uptime is decomposed into Engineering Time AND Standby Time AND Manufacturing Time, all of which occur only during Operations Time and are mutually exclusive at this level.
Engineering Time represents periods when the equipment is running for setup, calibration, testing, or adjustment rather than production.
Standby Time represents periods when the equipment is available but idle, waiting for materials, operators, or instructions.
Manufacturing Time represents periods when the equipment is actively used for production-related activities.
Manufacturing Time further contains Productive Time as a strict subset, where Productive Time refers specifically to periods during which acceptable output is being produced.
Thus, Productive Time is a subset of Manufacturing Time, Manufacturing Time is a subset of Equipment Uptime, Equipment Uptime is a subset of Operations Time, and Operations Time is a subset of Total Time.
This hierarchical decomposition defines a complete and non-overlapping model of equipment time states that supports availability, utilization, and productivity analysis while preserving clear semantic relationships between all time categories.  


  Key activities and conditions associated with the basic equipment states and substates are given in Figure 2.
The accumulated time in equipment states and substates are used in the metrics in this Document. The activities and
conditions associated with the basic equipment states and substates are described in the following sections. 


 1.5 Productive State (PRD) — The equipment state in which the equipment system is performing its intended
function, where the intended function includes performing within the specified operating conditions for which the
equipment system was built and configured. During an observation period, the accumulated time when thean
equipment system is in PRD is called productive time. This Document does not define or require mutually exclusive
substates for PRD, but PRD does include the following activities:
• Regular production (including loading and unloading of units internal to the equipment and conventional recipe
download)
• Work for a third party
• Rework
• Manufacturing support operations (e.g., processing test units to support other processes or equipment)
• Engineering runs done in conjunction with production units (e.g., split lots, new applications)
6.1.5.1 Support activities such as heating, cooling, purging, pump down, cleaning, etc., that are specified as part of
production recipes shall be specifically included in PRD. However, similar support activities that are not specified as
part of production recipes shall be specifically excluded from PRD.


 6.1.6 Standby State (SBY) — The equipment state, other than the nonscheduled state (NST), when the equipment
T
system is in a condition to perform its intended function and consumable materials and facilities are available, but the
O
equipment system is not operated. During an observation period, the accumulated time when thean equipment system
is in SBY is called standby time. This Document does not define or require mutually exclusive substates for SBY, but L
SBY does include the following activities: L
A
• No operator available (e.g., breaks, lunches, meetings)
B
• No units available (e.g., no units due to lack of available support equipment, such as metrology equipment)
L
• No support tool (e.g., wafer carrier, probe card) A
• Associated cluster tool equipment module down N
O
• No production test results available for review
I
• No input from external automation systems (e.g., host) T
A
• Waiting for loading or unloading
M
6.1.7 Engineering State (ENG) — The equipment state when the equipment system is in a condition to perform its
R
intended function (i.e., no equipment or process problems exist), but is operated to conduct engineering experiments,
especially where the usage of the equipment system is not indicative of normal production and may be asked to O
perform outside specified operating conditions. Failures under such extreme conditions should not be considered to F
arise from PRD. During an observation period, the accumulated time when thean equipment system is in ENG is called N
engineering time. This Document does not define or require mutually exclusive substates for ENG, but ENG does
I
include the following activities:
• Process engineering (e.g., process characterization)
• Equipment engineering (e.g., equipment evaluation)
• Software engineering (e.g., software qualification)
6.1.8 Scheduled Downtime State (SDT) — The equipment state when the equipment system is not available in a
condition to perform its intended function due to scheduled or planned activities or conditionsdowntime events. These
activities or conditionsevents may be based upon accumulated time, equipment usage (e.g., units, work), or equipment
conditions (e.g., predictive models). During an observation period, the accumulated time when thean equipment
system is in SDT is also called scheduled downtime. SDT is divided into the following mutually exclusive substates:
• SDT preventive maintenance
• SDT setup
• SDT maintenance delay, supplier
• SDT maintenance delay, nonsupplier
• SDT production test
• SDT change of consumable material
• SDT facilities related
• SDT unspecified
NOTE 5:NOTE 6: The substates SDT preventive maintenance; SDT setup; SDT maintenance delay, supplier; and SDT change of
consumable material are required to support accurate supplier-dependent and equipment-dependent metrics. Other SDT substates
are not used in these metrics. See §§ 8.3.3 and 8.3.4.
6.1.8.1 SDT Preventive Maintenance — SDT substate that includes the following procedures as specified by the
supplier as part of a preventive maintenance (PM) program:
• Preventive Action — A predefined preventive maintenance procedure (including equipment ramp-down and
ramp-up), at scheduled intervals or based upon predictive models, designed to reduce the likelihood of equipment failure during operation. Scheduled preventive maintenance intervals may be based upon accumulated time,
T
equipment usage (e.g., units, work), or equipment conditions (e.g., predictive models).
O
• Equipment Test — The operation of equipment after preventive action to demonstrate equipment functionality L
(e.g., chamber reaches base pressure, units transfer without problem, gas flow is correct, plasma ignites, source
L
reaches specified power).
A
• Verification Run — The processing and evaluation of units after preventive action to establish that the equipment B
is performing its intended function within specifications.
L
NOTE 6:NOTE 7: Equipment suppliers are responsible for recommending a PM program to achieve a predetermined equipment
A
performance level. Users are obligated to identify any deviation from the recommended program if they expect the supplier to meet
or improve that performance level. N
O
6.1.8.2 SDT Setup — SDT substate that includes the following activities related to a setup as specified by the supplier:
I
• Conversion — The procedure to complete an equipment alteration (hardware and--or software) necessary to T
accommodate a change in process, unit type, package configuration, etc., as part of normal production processing A
(excluding permanent modifications, rebuilds, and upgrades). Examples include parameter (e.g., beam current, M
temperature, gas flow) adjustment and handler adjustment.
R
• Equipment Test — The operation of equipment after conversion to demonstrate equipment functionality (e.g.,
O
chamber reaches base pressure, units transfer without problem, gas flow is correct, plasma ignites, source reaches
F
specified power).
N
• Verification Run — The processing and evaluation of units after conversion to establish that equipment is
I
performing its intended function within specifications.
NOTE 7:NOTE 8: Equipment suppliers are responsible for recommending procedures for conversion. Users are obligated to
identify any deviation from the recommended procedures.
NOTE 8:NOTE 9: Recipe download activities that are unusual or infrequent, that have especially significant durations, or that
require significant manual intervention should be tracked as conversions under SDT setup. Recipe download activities that are
regular, automated functions of processing should be tracked in PRD.
6.1.8.3 SDT Maintenance Delay, Supplier — SDT substate where the equipment cannot perform its intended function
because it is waiting for supplier personnel, supplier-controlled parts, supplier-controlled consumable materials, or
supplier-controlled information such as test results. An SDT maintenance delay substate may occur at any point during
SDT.
6.1.8.4 SDT Maintenance Delay, Nonsupplier — SDT substate where the equipment cannot perform its intended
function because it is waiting for nonsupplier personnel, nonsupplier-controlled parts, nonsupplier-controlled
consumable material, or nonsupplier-controlled information such as test results. An SDT maintenance delay substate
may occur at any point during SDT. An SDT maintenance delay substate may also be due to an administrative decision
to leave the equipment down and postpone maintenance.
6.1.8.5 SDT Production Test — SDT substate for the scheduled interruption of equipment uptime for evaluation of
units, as defined in the user specifications for equipment operation, to confirm that the equipment is performing its
intended function within specifications. It does not include testing that can be done in parallel with, or transparent to,
the running of production, and it does not include any testing done following a PM, setup, or repair procedure. It also
does not include waiting for test results.
6.1.8.6 SDT Change of Consumable Material — SDT substate for the scheduled interruption of equipment uptime to
change consumable material. It does not include delays in obtaining the consumable material, which are included in
either SDT maintenance delay, supplier or SDT maintenance delay, nonsupplier.
6.1.8.7 SDT Facilities-Related — SDT substate when the equipment cannot perform its intended function solely as a
result of scheduled out-of-specification facilities. Any scheduled downtime required by the facilities listed below shall
be included in the SDT facilities-related substate. For example, if otherwise unnecessary PM actions are needed as a
result of a scheduled facilities change, upgrade, or repair, all activities required to return the equipment to a condition
where it can perform its intended function are included in the SDT facilities-related substate. The facilities include:
• Environmental (e.g., temperature, humidity, vibration, particle count) Facility connections (e.g., power, cooling water, facility gases, exhaust, LN )
2
• Communications links with other equipment or host
6.1.9.11 UDT Unspecified — The substate for any unscheduled downtime that is not specifically tracked under one
of the above substates.


 6.1.10 Nonscheduled State (NST) — The equipment state whenin which the equipment system is not scheduled to be
T
utilized in production. During an observation period, the accumulated time an when the equipment system is in NST

does include the following activities: L

6.1.10.1 Unworked Time Periods — Shifts, weekends, holidays, facilities shutdowns, etc. out of the production
A
schedule.
M
6.1.10.2 Off-line Training — Equipment system is operated exclusively for training purposes that does not result in
R
any productive output.
O
6.1.10.3 Equipment Installation — Equipment system is out of the production schedule due to initial installation.
F
6.1.10.4 Equipment Modification — Equipment system is out of the production schedule due to modification, rebuild, N
or upgrade (hardware or software) that is not accommodated by the regular PM schedule.
I
6.1.10.5 Shutdown--Start-Up — Equipment system is out of the production schedule due to equipment shutdown and
start-up.
6.1.10.6 IPS Nonscheduled — IPS equipment system is not the current IPS or among the IPSs currently scheduled to
be utilized in production. See § 7.4.6.1 for more details on the IPS nonscheduled stateNST.
NOTE 10:NOTE 11: By tracking inactive IPSs in NST, productive time is more accurately attributed to active IPSs, directly
affecting metrics for IPSs involving productive time. To the extent that multiple IPSs are simultaneously active and have shared
processing equipment modules, productive time cannot be accurately attributed to individual IPSs, and metrics for IPSs involving
productive time may be less useful.
6.1.10.7 NST includes any qualification activities required to bring the equipment system to a condition where it can
perform its intended function after any nonscheduled activities like those listed above.
6.1.10.8 Any maintenance done to the equipment system cannot be counted in NST, since all maintenance (including
automatic maintenance routines such as a programmed cryopump regeneration) must shall be tracked in either SDT
or UDT.
6.1.10.9 By the same convention, any production or engineering work (including an unattended operation that may
shut itself off ‘after hours’) must shall be tracked in either PRD or ENG.
NOTE 11:NOTE 12: NST is intended for omission of strategically unworked periods from total time and should be generally
predetermined in a long-term production schedule. In general, random moment-to-moment periods of idling between productive
periods should be tracked in SBY rather than NST. The only notable exception may be for particularly agile MPCTs that frequently
switch IPSs (e.g., from lot-to-lot), where tracking inactive IPSs in NST aids in the accurate attribution of productive time to active
IPSs.
6.2 Tracking Requirements for Equipment Cycles — For support of certain SEMI E10 metrics, counts of equipment
cycles are also required for each observation period. A cycle is one complete operational sequence (including unit
load and unload) of processing, manufacturing, or testing steps for an equipment system or subsystem. In equipment
systems that process units individually, the number of cycles equals the number of units (e.g., wafers) processed. In
equipment systems that process units in batches, the number of cycles equals the number of batches processed.
6.2.1 Count of Equipment Cycles During Productive Time — The count of equipment cycles during productive time
is used in the metric MCBF .
p


 6.2.2 Count of Equipment Cycles During Uptime — The count of equipment cycles during productive time plus the
T
count of equipment cycles during engineering time. By definition of equipmentSEMI E10 states, there should shall be
O
no equipment cycles during standby time. The count of equipment cycles during uptime is used in the metric MCBF .
u
L
6.3 Tracking Requirements for Downtime Events — For each observation period, aside from aggregating the time in L
each equipmentSEMI E10 state and--or substate, downtime events for each equipment system must shall be tracked
A
and classified for use in SEMI E10 metrics.
B
6.3.1 Downtime Event — A downtime event is an initial equipment state transition event either (1) into SDT from an
equipment state other than SDT or (2) into UDT from an equipment state other than UDT. A downtime event can be L
a transition into UDT from SDT or vice versa. A downtime event is neither a substate transition within SDT nor a A
substate transition within UDT. N
6.3.2 Continuous Downtime Event — A downtime event starts when an equipment system transitions into a downtime O
state from an uptime nondowntime state or the nonscheduled state (NST). For example, a transition from PRD to a I
T
downtime state isstarts a continuous downtime event., but aA transition from SDT to UDT, or vice versa, is not stays
A
in a continuous downtime event. The count of continuous downtime events is used in the metric mean time off line
(MTOL). M
6.3.3 Preventive Maintenance (PM) Event — For a noncluster tool, an SPCT, or an individual equipment module, a R
PM event is a downtime event into SDT where the SDT preventive maintenance substate occurs before the equipment O
exits SDT; PM events for an IPS--MPCT are the aggregate set of PM events of its constituent equipment modules. The
F
count of PM events is used in the metric mean time to PM (MTTPM).
N
6.3.4 Failure Event — A failure event is an initial equipment state transition event for an equipment system from an
I
equipment state other than UDT to UDT. A failure event is a downtime event transitioning into UDT. For a noncluster
tool, an SPCT, or an individual equipment module, a failure event may also be is classified as a repair event if a repair
substate occurs before the equipment exits UDT; repair events for an IPS--MPCT are the aggregate set of repair events
of its constituent equipment modules. Failure events are classified as follows:
6.3.4.1 Failure During Productive Time — A failure event from PRD. This includes failures that occur while
attempting the transition into PRD. The count of failures during productive time is used in the metrics MTBF and
p
MCBF .
p
6.3.4.2 Failure During Uptime — A failure event from PRD, SBY, or ENG. This includes failures that occur while
attempting the transition into those equipment states. The count of failures during uptime is used in the metrics MTBF
u
and MCBF .
u
6.3.4.3 Equipment-Related Failure During Productive Time — A failure event from PRD where the UDT repair time,
equipment-related substate occurs before the equipment system exits the UDT related to the failure event. The count
of equipment-related failures during productive time is used in the metrics E-MTBF and E-MCBF .
p p
6.3.4.4 Equipment-Related Failure During Uptime — A failure event from PRD, SBY, or ENG where the UDT repair
time, equipment-related substate occurs before the equipment exits the UDT related to the failure event. The count of
equipment-related failures during uptime is used in the metrics E-MTBF and E-MCBF .
u u
6.3.4.5 Equipment-Related Repair Event — For a noncluster tool, an SPCT, or an individual equipment module, an
equipment-related repair event is a failure event where the UDT repair time, equipment-related substate occurs before
the equipment system exits UDT. For an IPS--MPCT, the count of equipment-related repair events used in these metrics
is the aggregate count of equipment module-level equipment-related repair events. The count of equipment-related
repair events is used in the metrics MTTR and E-MTTR.
6.3.4.6 Nonequipment-Related Repair Event — For a noncluster tool, an SPCT, or an individual equipment module,
a nonequipment-related repair event is a failure event where the UDT repair time, nonequipment-related substate
occurs—and the UDT repair time, equipment-related substate does not occur—before the equipment exits UDT. For
an IPS--MPCT, the count of nonequipment-related repair events used in this metric is the aggregate count of equipment
module-level nonequipment-related repair events. The count of nonequipment-related repair events is used in the
metric MTTR.
NOTE 12:NOTE 13: It is legitimate to have ‘repairless’ failures that contain neither of the substates UDT repair time,
nonequipment-related substate or the UDT repair time, equipment-related.

equipment performance tracking system. Temporal mapping also may can be performed in batch mode at report time. M
Regardless, a logic function is applied at each input equipment state transition event to derive an output equipment
R
state value as a function of the input equipment state values.
O
7.4.5 There are different types of temporal mapping depending on the target equipmentSEMI E10 state to be evaluated.
F

NOTE 15:NOTE 16: Related Information 2 provides an example MPCT scenario including temporal mapping of IPSs and MPCT.
7.4.6 Temporal Mapping of the Six Basic EquipmentSEMI E10 States for an IPS — This section provides the logical
flow for determining the equipmentSEMI E10 state of an IPS based on the equipmentSEMI E10 states of its
constituent equipment modules and on a direct designation of NST for the IPS as a whole. Figure 4 illustrates this
logical flow. 


 The figure defines a temporal decision logic for mapping Equipment Module SEMI E10 states to a single IPS (Integrated Production System) SEMI E10 state, based on the tracked time category and reliability status of equipment modules.
The mapping process begins by checking whether the IPS is tracked in NST (Nonscheduled Time), and if this condition is true, the resulting state is assigned as IPS in NST, meaning the IPS state directly follows nonscheduled tracking.
If the IPS is not tracked in NST, then the IPS is considered to be in Operations Time, and the decision logic proceeds to evaluate activity within operations.
The next decision checks whether any processing equipment modules are in PRD (Productive Time), and if at least one module is processing in PRD, the resulting state is assigned as IPS in PRD, indicating that productive activity dominates the IPS state.
If no equipment modules are processing in PRD, the logic evaluates IPS reliability based only on UDT (Unscheduled Downtime) equipment modules.
If the IPS reliability function evaluated over UDT equipment modules equals zero, meaning those modules are down, the resulting state is assigned as IPS in pure UDT, representing unscheduled downtime conditions only.
If the IPS is not in pure UDT, the logic evaluates IPS reliability based only on SDT (Scheduled Downtime) equipment modules.
If the IPS reliability function evaluated over SDT equipment modules equals zero, meaning those scheduled-downtime modules are down, the resulting state is assigned as IPS in SDT.
If the IPS is neither in pure UDT nor in SDT, the logic evaluates IPS reliability based on the combined set of UDT and SDT equipment modules.
If the IPS reliability function evaluated over the combined UDT and SDT equipment modules equals zero, meaning the IPS is down due to a mixture of scheduled and unscheduled downtime, the resulting state is assigned as IPS in mixed UDT.
If none of the downtime-based reliability conditions are satisfied, the logic then checks whether any equipment modules are in ENG (Engineering Time).
If at least one equipment module is in ENG, the resulting state is assigned as IPS in ENG, representing engineering or setup-related activity at the IPS level.
If no equipment modules are in ENG, the remaining default operational condition is assigned as IPS in SBY (Standby Time), indicating that the IPS is available but idle.
Overall, this decision sequence defines a priority-ordered temporal mapping in which NST overrides all other states, PRD overrides downtime and nonproductive states within operations time, downtime states are distinguished by scheduled versus unscheduled reliability conditions, engineering activity overrides standby, and standby represents the residual operational state when no higher-priority conditions apply.  



8 RAM and Utilization Measurement I
8.1 Observation Periods for Metrics
8.1.1 To calculate metrics, an observation period shall be specified and agreed upon by the user and the supplier.
Appendix 1 ¶ A1-2.9 provides some guidance on establishing the observation period time needed to demonstrate a
desired mean time between failures (MTBF) at a given confidence level.
8.1.2 For any equipment system, the following rules shall be followed to ensure that over multiple observation periods,
neither downtime events nor downtime is ever double-counted.
8.1.2.1 The count of downtime events including failure events that occur during the observation period are included
in all applicable metrics regardless of when the related downtime state is exited. The count of downtime events that
occur before the observation period are not included in metrics even if the related downtime state is exited during or
after the observation period.
8.1.2.2 Downtime time that occurs during the observation period is counted in all applicable metrics regardless of the
start time or end time of the downtime state. For a downtime event that occurs prior to the observation period, the
portion of downtime time that occurs within the observation period is still counted. Hence, an observation period
canmay have associated downtime time without a downtime event occurring during that observation period.
8.1.3 Observation periods shall be specified of appropriate duration so that divide-by-zero errors for metrics are
unlikely.
8.1.3.1 For the equipment reliability metrics defined in § 8.2, the possibility exists of having the case of zero failures,
zero downtime events, etc. in the denominators resulting in a divide-by-zero error, especially for shorter observation
periods or highly reliable equipment. In these cases, the single-value point estimates for these metrics cannot be
calculated and are therefore undefined. However, a lower confidence bound (LCB) estimate can still be calculated
(see § 9.6), but an upper confidence bound (UCB) estimate cannot.
8.1.3.2 For the equipment maintainability metrics defined in § 8.4, the possibility exists of having the case of zero
PM events, zero repair events, or zero downtime events in the denominators resulting in a divide-by-zero error,
especially for shorter observation periods, low maintenance equipment, or highly reliable equipment. In these cases,
the singe-value point estimates for these metrics cannot be calculated and are therefore undefined. For these metrics
calculating LCB and UCB estimates is not appropriate (see § 9.4).
NOTE 25:NOTE 26: Related Information 2 provides an example MPCT usage scenario including calculations of all metrics.

time. Only uptime is included in this calculation. Failures that occur coincident with an attempt to change from NST
or SDT to an uptime state are included in this calculation. L

  This section defines Mean Time Between Failures (MTBF)–related reliability metrics as calculated over specific equipment time states, explicitly distinguishing uptime, productive time, and failure categories.
MTBF_u, or mean uptime between failures, is defined as the average equipment system uptime during which the equipment was capable of performing its intended function between successive failures, and it is computed as total uptime divided by the number of failures that occurred during uptime.
Only uptime is included in the MTBF_u calculation, and failures that occur coincident with an attempt to change from NST (Nonscheduled Time) or SDT (Scheduled Downtime) to an uptime state are explicitly included in the failure count.
Formally, MTBF_u equals uptime divided by the number of failures during uptime.
MFD_u, or mean failure duration during uptime, is defined as the average unscheduled downtime resulting from failures that occurred during uptime, and it is computed as total unscheduled downtime caused by failures during uptime divided by the number of failures during uptime.
Formally, MFD_u equals unscheduled downtime for failures during uptime divided by the number of failures during uptime.
E-MTBF_u, or mean uptime time between equipment-related failures, is defined as the average equipment system uptime between failures that are specifically classified as equipment-related, and it is computed as total uptime divided by the number of equipment-related failures that occurred during uptime.
Only uptime is included in the E-MTBF_u calculation, and equipment-related failures that occur coincident with an attempt to change from NST or SDT to an uptime state are included in the equipment-related failure count.
Formally, E-MTBF_u equals uptime divided by the number of equipment-related failures during uptime.
MTBF_p, or mean productive time between failures, is defined as the average productive time during which the equipment performed its intended function between failures, and it is computed as total productive time divided by the number of failures that occurred during productive time.
Only productive time is included in the MTBF_p calculation, and failures that occur when an attempt is made to change from any equipment state other than UDT (Unscheduled Downtime) to PRD (Productive Time) are included in the failure count.
Formally, MTBF_p equals productive time divided by the number of failures during productive time.
Together, these metrics establish state-specific reliability measures that explicitly bind failure counts and durations to well-defined equipment time states such as uptime, productive time, NST, SDT, and UDT, enabling consistent reliability analysis aligned with SEMI E10 time and state definitions. 



 This section explains how MTBF can be used as a risk parameter under the assumption that times between failures follow an exponential distribution.
It is assumed that analysts believe the exponential distribution is representative of the time between failures and that MTBF is the correct parameter characterizing that distribution.
Under this assumption, measures of risk for specific operational scenarios can be estimated by computing the probability that a system survives without failure for a given duration expressed as a percentage of MTBF.
Survival time is therefore modeled as a random variable whose survival probability decreases exponentially as elapsed time increases relative to MTBF.
Table R1-1 presents the probability of survival time expressed as a percentage of MTBF, explicitly linking survival probability to multiples of MTBF under the exponential distribution assumption.
For example, if MTBF equals 500 hours, then a survival duration of 1000 hours corresponds to 200 percent of MTBF, and the probability of surviving without failure for that duration is 13.5 percent.
The table shows that at 25 percent of MTBF the probability of survival is 77.9 percent, at 50 percent of MTBF the probability is 60.7 percent, at 75 percent of MTBF the probability is 47.2 percent, and at 100 percent of MTBF the probability is 36.8 percent.
As survival time increases beyond MTBF, the probability of survival decreases rapidly, with probabilities of 22.3 percent at 150 percent of MTBF, 13.5 percent at 200 percent of MTBF, 5.0 percent at 300 percent of MTBF, 1.8 percent at 400 percent of MTBF, and 0.7 percent at 500 percent of MTBF.
These values illustrate how MTBF, when used as the scale parameter of an exponential distribution, enables quantitative estimation of survival probability and operational risk for time horizons expressed as multiples of MTBF.


 This section explains the relationship between SEMI E58 (ARAMS) and SEMI E10 with respect to automated reliability, availability, and maintainability data and their underlying equipment state models.
 SEMI E58 (ARAMS) provides automated data collection support that aligns with an earlier version of the SEMI E10 standard, which makes the correlation between the two standards particularly clear for productive time.
Within this alignment, the SEMI E10 productive time state PRD is explicitly intended to be synonymous with the ARAMS productive state PRD, meaning both standards use PRD to represent the time during which the equipment system is performing its intended function.
This equivalence establishes that productive time measured under SEMI E10 maps directly to productive time measured under SEMI E58 ARAMS without semantic transformation.
Figure R1-4 presents the ARAMS equipment state model, which depicts the ARAMS interpretation of equipment time states within the context of total time.
In the ARAMS model, Total Time is the outermost state and contains all other equipment states, including Manufacturing, Scheduled Downtime, Unscheduled Downtime, Nonscheduled Downtime, and Engineering.
Manufacturing is a major operational state within Total Time and contains both Standby and Productive substates.
The Productive state within Manufacturing represents the time during which the equipment system is actively performing its intended production function, and this state corresponds directly to PRD in SEMI E10.
Standby represents time within Manufacturing during which the equipment is available but not actively producing.
Transitions exist between Standby and Productive, indicating movement between idle-ready and active production conditions.
Scheduled Downtime represents planned interruptions, while Unscheduled Downtime represents unplanned failures or breakdowns, and both can be entered from Manufacturing-related states.
Engineering represents time spent on engineering activities such as setup, testing, or adjustment and is distinct from Manufacturing.
Nonscheduled Downtime represents periods outside the planned operational schedule and exists within Total Time but outside Manufacturing.
The ARAMS state model therefore organizes equipment behavior as a hierarchy of Total Time containing operational, downtime, and engineering states, with Productive PRD explicitly identified as the state in which intended function is performed.
By defining PRD as synonymous across SEMI E58 and SEMI E10, the standards ensure consistent interpretation of productive time for reliability, availability, and maintainability analysis across automated data collection and equipment performance metrics.
